item.title: A Single Datum
item.description: A Single Datum A Distribution Does Not Make The wrong distribution can be imposed if we center our uncertainty on just one observation.

item.title: Repeated Trials
item.description: Better estimates of the distribution’s center arise from averaging over more data. $$Q(\lambda)= \frac{1}{M} \sum_{j=1}^{M}O_j$$ This is how we can improve the vector-valued posterior density.

item.title: Assimilation
item.description:
Repeated Trials We could instead define a misfit function as our QoI instead. This effectively turns our QoI into a scalar-valued map. \(\newcommand{\lam}{(\lambda)}\) \(\newcommand{\qoi}{Q\lam}\) $$\qoi = \frac{1}{M} \sum_{i=1}^M \left(\frac{O_i\lam-d_i}{\sigma_i}\right)^2$$ This represents our average deviation from the data.
What are the differences?
